title: In Atlanta Suburb, Republicans See an Uphill Battle
text:
DULUTH, Ga.—Gwinnett County in Atlanta’s suburbs has been a Republican stronghold since Ronald Reagan beat Jimmy Carter in the 1980 presidential election, but an influx of minorities has transformed it, creating a possible Democratic juggernaut for 2020.

“If the Republicans don’t broaden their base, they are in serious trouble,” said Fran Millar, a former Republican state senator who lost his re-election bid last year. No matter how much he campaigned, “It didn’t matter. I had the ‘R’ next to my name,” said Mr. Millar, whose district was partly in Gwinnett.

Hot-button issues, including President Trump’s calls to limit immigration and a GOP-backed state abortion law, are driving people of color and women in suburban Atlanta to the Democrats, Mr. Millar said.

The county’s shift from predominantly white and Republican to Democratic-leaning and diverse is part of a national trend that includes California’s Orange County and two less populous Atlanta suburban counties, Cobb and Henry, said Andra Gillespie, an Emory University political-science professor. Minorities and immigrants are moving in large numbers to suburban areas where rents are often cheaper, she said.

“Gwinnett is on the front line,” she said.

Those growing areas—blue dots in what had been a sea of red—are playing a larger role in elections across the South, including Georgia.

Gwinnett, northeast of downtown Atlanta, is a web of subdivisions, apartment complexes, shopping centers and single-family houses typical of the sprawling metro region. It is home to Atlanta commuters and those working across the northern suburbs, from executives to service workers.

The GOP’s dominance in the county started to unravel in 2016 when an influx of minorities and immigrants delivered a surprise: Democrat Hillary Clinton won Gwinnett by 51% to 45% for Donald Trump, even as Mrs. Clinton lost the state. In 2018, Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams carried Gwinnett by a wide margin as she narrowly lost her bid to Republican Brian Kemp. Several Democrats down-ticket in the county won, knocking out Republicans who had held office for decades.

Georgians waiting in line to cast their votes in the 2018 U.S. midterm election at a Gwinnett County polling place in Snellville, Ga. Photo: leah millis/Reuters

The prospect makes Republicans anxious and Democrats excited. Voter-registration data from the Georgia secretary of state’s office show how crucial Gwinnett, with 927,000 people and growing, could be in 2020. In July 2019, Gwinnett had more than 549,000 registered voters, a 40% increase from July 2016. In 2019, about 44% of Gwinnett’s registered voters were black, Hispanic or Asian, up from about 37% three years earlier.

Ms. Abrams, who heads a group called Fair Fight Action pressing for changes in how votes are cast and counted, has made it clear Gwinnett will be a focus. When she announced a national campaign on vote counting in August, her first public event in Georgia was at a Gwinnett elementary school where voting machines malfunctioned in 2018.

Both parties see Atlanta’s swelling suburbs as pivotal in 2020, not just for the presidential contest, but for the state’s two Senate seats, both of which will be up for grabs. GOP Sen. David Perdue, a vocal Trump supporter, is up for re-election. GOP Sen. Johnny Isakson, 74 years old, who has Parkinson’s disease, announced in August that he will retire at the end of this year. Gov. Kemp will appoint someone to temporarily fill the post and then hold a special election for the last two years of Mr. Isakson’s term in November 2020.

Bianca Keaton, a former Abrams campaign staffer who now is the first woman to chair the Gwinnett County Democratic Party, said candidates and volunteers are clamoring to work on Democratic campaigns in her county.

“Countywide, it’s not a good time to be a Republican,” said Ms. Keaton, 36, who is African-American.

Ms. Keaton is the first woman to chair the Gwinnett County Democratic Party. Photo: Dustin Chambers for Wall Street Journal

In 2018, Democrats won two of the county’s five commissioner posts. Democrats are confident they can win the remaining three next year, Ms. Keaton said.

Julianne Thompson, a Gwinnett-based Republican strategist who serves on the national advisory board of Women for Trump 2020, said her party was caught off guard in Gwinnett during recent elections, but it will campaign aggressively in 2020, targeting conservative voters to make sure they get to the polls.

“The Republican Party has learned a lot of lessons, including about get-out-the-vote efforts in rapidly changing communities like Gwinnett County,” she said.

Charlotte Nash, the Republican county commission chairwoman, declined to comment. Danny Porter, the longtime Republican county prosecutor, told the Gwinnett Daily Post this year that he might switch to be a Democrat in the 2020 race to ensure a win. He didn’t respond to repeated requests for comment.

In 2016, whites made up just over half of the registered voters in Gwinnett, according to secretary of state data. This year they make up just under 42%.

The county now is home to a large Korean population, one of the largest Hindu temples in North America and numerous other immigrant communities, from Dominicans to Chinese. It is also poorer. In 2017, 12.3% of the county lived in poverty, according to the census. In 2000, 5.7% of residents lived in poverty.

Downtown Lithonia in Gwinnett County. Photo: Dustin Chambers for Wall Street Journal

The Gwinnett Place Mall, a bustling center for traditional suburban shopping when it opened in 1984, now is mostly vacant. Netflix rented a portion of the mall to film its series “Stranger Things.” Indian-American developers have proposed tearing the mall down and replacing it with a cricket stadium.

Shayla Walker, 42, an African-American who has lived in the county for 19 years, said Republicans haven’t been listening to the needs of minority voters and are paying the price at the polls.

“You have to give people some incentive to keep voting for you,” she said.

Dwayne Menser, 59, a white retired finance executive, visited the mall recently with his family to see the “Stranger Things” set. Mr. Menser, a longtime Gwinnett resident who described himself as “a very conservative Republican,” said he has noticed political tensions rising among neighbors in recent years.

“Both sides have to find a way to ratchet down the rhetoric,” he said.

Write to Cameron McWhirter at cameron.mcwhirter@wsj.com
description: Gwinnett County in Atlanta’s suburbs has been a Republican stronghold since Ronald Reagan beat Jimmy Carter in the 1980 election, but an influx of minorities has created a possible Democratic juggernaut for 2020.
